subject: monitor: Subscribe to tach target and feedback services
commitMessage:
monitor: Subscribe to tach target and feedback services

Subscribes to nameOwnerChanged signals for the services of the sensor
and target interfaces for each configured fan. If those services go
offline, the fan tach sensors should get marked nonfunctional due to no
longer receiving updated target or feedback values. In this design, we
use the existing method of determining when a fan tach sensor should be
marked nonfunctional to allow a recovery window, wherein a brief
offline/online transition (such as during a restart) will not trigger a
nonfunctional state change.

Change-Id: I0a935ccad5a864dc952d023185356a1ef1226830
Signed-off-by: Mike Capps <mikepcapps@gmail.com>

FWIW, I know you're working on a fix to the tach sensors in inventory but I loaded this change up and did not see the secondary (fan*_1) sensors associated with the same service as the primary (fan*_0) sensors. Once we get the tach sensors in inventory fixed up, I think it'd be good to load this change on top of that to make sure things are working as expected.

this spacing is a little funky.
If you happen to use vim to edit commit messages and don't already have this, you can add:
autocmd Filetype gitcommit setlocal spell textwidth=72

Then you can use 'gqip' or similar to format for you.
how would these get marked nonfunctional?  Is that happening today and maybe I just forgot?
It happens via: Fan::process() -> Fan::updateState() -> Fan::setFunctional() -> TachSensor::setFunctional()
This is okay to put when it's an issue under the openbmc project, but since it's in ibm-openbmc we  really shouldn't point to it from a commit message.
So I said this could be done like this so it links back to the upstream issue. I suppose would could just point from the ibm-openbmc issue up to this review.
Would you consider moving this into a function called from here? addNameOwnerChangedMatches or whatever.

you can do this in the line above with a structured binding (maybe you knew this and chose not to, but in case you didn't):

for (const auto& [name, services] : objects)
since tacah_signal_offline takes a reference, and sensor_map is local to this function, does it end up using a dangling_reference, or does std::bind capture it somehow?

I checked it against the std::bind() documentation on cppreference.com and it says args to bind are always copied or moved. I think we're safe. However, now that I've separated the function that creates the map, it's probably no longer necessary to pass it as an arg (presuming the function wont return different values the 2nd time it's called).
The coding guidelines say to use camelCase as the C++ naming convention.
is this used?  maybe I missed it.
its in monitor/system.cpp +254, it's how we actually make the sensor go on/offline
I think it might be a good idea to sneak a trace somewhere in here that says some sensors were detected going on/offline

When the sensor does not have an owner, dont we want to immediately return true here so Fan::process starts/continues the appropriate method of updating the functional state?

Right now this appears to say a sensor would never be "out of range" when its no longer owned by a service, yet we do want it to be deemed not "in range"...just not do the range calculation.
Instead of the extra temporary reference, could use `service_itr.first` here

Probably should include the target interface in the getSubTree call so that all objects & services for both the sensor and target interfaces are returned in the single call. As you'll see, the interface passed to getSubTree is put into vector when the method call is made to the mapper.

This would require a new `getSubTree` method in SDBusPlus or the use of callMethodAndRead directly.
I'm still working on this. Ack-ing it for now.
What does the '2' represent here? Can it just be "fan"?
Doesnt `sensorMap` use the service name as the key? This appears to be using the target interface...
I think we want both, right? Because there are two interfaces that can go offline. Is there anything wrong with doing it this way?

Yes, but you lose the service name in this case, which is what you need to be able to subscribe to. For this entry, you'd have to do another lookup for the service name since its not saved in `sensorMap`.

You may want to consider using the same data type structure that getSubTree returns since it packs the list of interfaces per service name for a dbus object path

getSubTree returns = map<string, map<string, vector>>
which equates to map<"PATH", map<"SERVICE", "LIST OF INTERFACES">>
`hasOwner` or `isOwned` seems more appropriate for this variable name.
Please update to match variable name = `sensorMap`

Shouldn't this be

  const auto&

Maybe they mean the same thing, but the ordering seems strange.

sensorMap is a local variable, meaning it goes away when System::start() ends.

Does std::bind() cause a persistent copy of sensorMap to be made (like a lambda capture by value)?

If not, you will be passing garbage to the tachSignalOffline() method, since that will be called at some point in the future after System::start() has ended.

One way to fix, if it makes sense, is to make sensorMap a data member.  Then it persists and doesn't need to be passed.

I looked into this, see 2nd paragraph under notes: https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/functional/bind . Also I wrote a test-program with a non-copyable test-object and it fails to compile when bound to a const& function. DM me for details.

I think you can skip the std::move() here and just make the getSubTreeRaw() parameter a const SensorMapType&.  That will avoid the copy, and its not like getSubTreeRaw() is taking permanent ownership of the memory; it is just using it for a single function call.
Is this necessary?  I think (?) fmt supports std::string arguments.
Nit: Seems like this sentence is missing a word or two.  It doesn't quite make sense.
Should this be"const SensorMapType&"?  The reference itself isn't going to change, so noting it as constant is not needed.
both syntax are logically equivalent, I just developed a habit from a previous codebase. However, I changed it to be consisted with the format used here.
I dont believe what you're doing in the try clause throws a DBusError exception does it? or even anything we'd want to catch really...
I checked one layer up in match.hpp and it doesn't appear to throw. and I agree we dont want to consume it if it did.
I dont see utility.hpp included so it must be getting this indirectly?

nit: Actually its "Set all sensors' owner state to not owned"

Each sensor's functional state will be updated accordingly using the method and duration configured while not have a service owner.
